questions.question: The most calorically dense macronutrient is
questions.explanation: Fat is the most calorically dense macronutrient, providing approximately 9 calories per gram, whereas protein and carbohydrates provide approximately 4 calories per gram.

questions.question: The mother of a school-going child is worried that he eats a lot of junk food. She is anxious to learn about the healthy diet to be followed in the child. You would ideally advise the mother to restrict the dietary intake of saturated fat to less than a percentage of total energy intake.
questions.explanation: According to current dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be <10% of total energy intake. Current dietary guidelines for children and adolescents: Total fat should account for <30% of total daily energy, saturated fat less than 10% of total daily energy, dietary cholesterol <300 mg/day, and no trans-fat.

questions.question: Your school friend, the mother of a four-year-old child gives you a casual call. She had recently noticed an ad on margarine being a better alternative over butter/ghee and wishes to seek your opinion about adding it to her son's diet. What percentage of total daily energy requirement in children can come from margarine?
questions.explanation: Margarine and other hydrogenated oils are trans fat. Trans fat is not recommended in children according to current dietary guidelines. Current dietary guidelines for children and adolescents: • Total fat should account for <30% of total daily energy • Saturated fat less than 10% of total daily energy • Dietary cholesterol <300 mg/day • No trans-fat

questions.question: A newborn baby is ready to be discharged. As a part of your discharge advice, for how many months would you recommend exclusive breastfeeding?
questions.explanation: Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for 6 months. Complementary foods rich in iron and other micronutrients should be introduced at about 6 months of age. Breastfeeding should continue for at least the first year.

questions.question: You are taking a neonatal case for presentation during your postings. The mother tells you that the child is exclusively breastfed. Which of the following is least likely to corroborate with this history of being exclusively breastfed?
questions.explanation: Exclusively breastfed infants are least likely to have evening colic. The incidence of diarrhea, allergy to bovine milk, and atopic eczema are least reported in exclusively breastfed infants. Option A: Vitamin K content of milk is low and may contribute to hemorrhagic disease of the newborn. Option B: Breast milk contains inhibitors of glucuronyl transferase and enhances absorption of bilirubin from the gut. This leads to the development of breast milk jaundice. Option C: During the first few days, the breastfed infant has a black-green colored stool. It changes to golden yellow by the end of the first week.

questions.question: Which of the following mothers can initiate breastfeeding?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 2 and 5 only. Breastfeeding is not contraindicated if the mother has hepatitis B infection or if she is a chronic smoker. Infants born to an HbsAg positive mother routinely receive hepatitis B immunoglobulin and hepatitis B vaccine. So, a delay in the initiation of breastfeeding is not required. Alcohol consumption and smoking are NOT contraindications of breastfeeding. However, smoking and alcohol consumption should be discouraged. Note: In a mother with untreated, active tuberculosis: Temporarily withhold breastfeeding but can feed with expressed breastmilk. Resume breastfeeding once she has been adequately treated for 2 weeks and is no longer contagious. Contraindications of breastfeeding: Do not Breastfeed; Do not give expressed breastmilk; Do not Breastfeed (Temporarily); Do not give expressed breastmilk (Temporarily); Do not Breastfeed (Temporarily); Can give expressed breastmilk. Infant factors: Classic galactosemia. Maternal factors: Human T-cell lymphotropic virus (HTLV) infection, Ebola virus infection, PCP/cocaine abuse. Maternal factors: Brucellosis, undergoing diagnostic imaging with radiopharmaceuticals, Active herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection with lesions on the breasts. Maternal factors: Untreated, active Tuberculosis, Active Varicella infection.

questions.question: As a part of your neonatal rotation, you are asked to assess the adequacy of breastfeeding and breastfeeding techniques in a primi mother. Which of the following would be an indicator of inadequate breastfeeding in the neonate?

options.A: Baby sleeping for 2-3 hours after feed

questions.explanation: Weight loss of >7-10% of birth weight is an indicator of inadequate breastfeeding in a neonate. Indicators of inadequate breastfeeding in the newborn: •Weight loss >7-10 % of birth weight •Lethargy (sleeping longer than 2-3 hours) •Delayed passage of stools (Less than 4 times/day) •Decreased urine output (urinating less than 5-7 times/day) •Hypernatremic dehydration •Inconsolable crying and increased hunger. Insufficient milk intake may be caused by insufficient milk production, failure of established breastfeeding, and health conditions in the infant that prevent proper breast stimulation. Breastfed neonates usually feed 8-12 times a day, with a minimum of 8 times per day. However, the neonate should be breastfed only on demand.

questions.question: For how long can freshly expressed breast milk be stored at room temperature?
questions.explanation: Expressed breast milk can be stored at room temperature for 6-8 hours. Note: This is a controversial question. A difference of opinion among authors is noted regarding the refrigeration of expressed breast milk. Nelson's (21st ed, page 324) mentions that breast milk can be refrigerated and used within 48 hours and frozen for around 6 months. However, AIIMS in collaboration with WHO recommends that breast milk can be refrigerated up to 24 hours and frozen at -20 degrees C for about 3 months. Expressed breast milk Stored for / Used within (maximum time) Room Temperature: 6 hours, In refrigerator: 24 hours, Frozen breast milk at -20°C: 3 months

questions.question: Shrija, a working mother planning to resume her work, wishes to know more about expressed breast milk. Within how many hours would you advise her to use the refrigerated expressed breast milk?
questions.explanation: Breast milk stored in the refrigerator should be used within 24 hours. Refrigerated or frozen milk should be thawed rapidly by holding under running tepid water and used completely within 24 hours after thawing. Milk should never be microwaved. Note: This is a controversial question. A difference of opinion among authors is noted regarding the refrigeration of expressed breast milk. Nelson's (21st ed, page 324) mentions that breast milk can be refrigerated and used within 48 hours and frozen for around 6 months. However, AIIMS in collaboration with WHO recommends that breast milk can be refrigerated up to 24 hours and frozen at -20 degree C for about 3 months. Expressed breast milk Stored for / Used within (maximum time) Room Temperature In refrigerator 6 hours 24 hours. Expressed breast milk Stored for / Used within (maximum time) Frozen breast milk at -20°C 3 months

questions.question: An anxious new mother feeding her child with expressed breastmilk (EBM) feels that theconsistency and colour of her milk have changed recently. She adds that when she expressesbreastmilk, the colour and consistency of the first portion and the ending portion iscompletely different and that she is worried about the same. Which statement is not trueabout different breast milk?

options.B: Mature milk is thicker with all the essential nutrients for growth
options.C: Foremilk is watery and is rich in proteins and sugar
options.D: Hindmilk is richer in fat and provides more energy

questions.explanation: Mature milk is thinner (not thicker) with all essential nutrients for growth.Various transitional forms of breastmilk:Colostrum•In the initial 3 to 4 days•Small quantity, thick, and yellow in colour• A large number of antibodies, immune component cells; and vitamins A, D, E, and K.Transitional milk• Secreted after 3 to 4 days until 2 weeks• Immunoglobulin and protein content decreases, while the fat and sugar content increases.Mature milk•Follows transitional milk.• Thinner and more watery.• Contains all the nutrients essential for the optimal growth of the baby.Foremilk• Secreted at the start of the feed••Watery and rich in proteins, sugar, vitamins, minerals, and water that quenches the baby'sthirst.Hindmilk• Comes towards the end of the feed• Provides more energy and a sense of satiety and it is richer in fat.Preterm milk.• Milk of mother who delivers before 37 weeks..Contains more proteins, sodium, iron, immunoglobins, and calories as per the requirement ofthe preterm infant.The given image shows watery foremilk and hindmilk which is rich in fat.111

questions.question: Following the delivery of a healthy baby boy, his COVID-positive mother slipped into ARDS and passed away. The relatives have arranged a breast milk donor and wish to feed the baby using the device shown in the image. In newborns of which gestational age would you recommend this as a method of primary feeding?
questions.explanation: The given image shows paladai. It can be used as a primary feeding method during routine feeding in neonates born at gestational age 32-34 weeks only. Sick mothers or mothers with contraindications to breastfeeding can feed their child using paladai. The milk can either be expressed breastmilk or they can resort to using undiluted cow milk or formula feeds. Choice of initial feeding methods in low-birth-weight (LBW) infants: Method of Feeding Gestational Age Feeding Skill Maturity <28 weeks: No proper sucking effort. No propulsive motility of the gut. 28-32 weeks: Sucking bursts develop. No coordination between suck/swallow and breathing. 32-34 weeks: Slightly mature sucking pattern. Coordination between breathing and swallowing begins. >34 weeks: Mature sucking pattern. More coordination between breathing and swallowing. IV Fluids, Oro-gastric/ Nasogastric tube feeding with occasional spoon/paladai feeding, Feeding by spoon/paladai/cup, Breastfeeding.

questions.question: A 2-month-old child is brought to your OPD with complaints of diarrhoea. The mother wantsto know if she should continue breastfeeding. Which of these components in breast milk,beneficial in intestinal cell maturation and repair, prompt you to advise her to continuebreastfeeding?
questions.explanation: The epidermal growth factor present in breastmilk helps in intestinal cell maturation and repair.This is why mothers are advised to continue breastfeeding in an infant affected with diarrhoea.It is also beneficial in luminal surveillance.Lactoferrin (Option A) helps in immunomodulation, iron chelation, antimicrobial action. It is alsoan antiadhesive and trophic for intestinal growth.Para-aminobenzoic acid (Option C) is present in low levels and offers protection againstplasmodium.Glutathione peroxidase (Option D) prevents lipid oxidation.

questions.question: A young working mother wants to add formula feeds to the diet of her 5-month-old child asshe would be unable to breastfeed her baby frequently and satiate her. Which of the followingfatty acid should the mother look for in the formula to ensure optimal brain development inthe child?
questions.explanation: Docosahexenoic acid (DHA) and arachidonic acid (ARA), both play an important role in thegrowth and CNS development in babies.DHA and ARA are essential poly unsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) present in breast milk.Both are essential for cognition functions, visual acuity, and immune responses. They haveoptimal effects on brain development when included together, in efficacious levels, in an infant'sdiet.Almost all infant formulae are now fortified with pre-formed DHA and ARA.It is advisable that all infants upto 6 months of age are to be exclusively breastfed and not formulafed. However, in unavoidable situations such as lactation failure or maternal infections wherebreastfeeding is contraindicated, the use of a formula feed that contains both DHA and ARA isrecommended.Other options:• Eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and Linolenic acid are other essential fatty acids that are present inbreast milk.113• These are required for the overall protection of the cardiovascular system as well as to reducesystemic inflammation.

questions.question: 105An exclusively breastfed neonate in his 4th week of life was found to be jaundiced. His stoolsare yellow and urine appears pale straw, he is otherwise well. A provisional diagnosis ofbreastmilk jaundice is made. Which of the following is false about this condition?

options.B: Some babies need treatment with phototherapy
options.D: It is common in the second week of life

questions.explanation: Breastfeeding is not contraindicated in breast milk jaundice. Mothers are advised to continuebreastfeeding at frequent intervals.Breastmilk jaundice is seen in about 2-4% of exclusively breastfed babies. There is significantunconjugated hyperbilirubinemia after the 7th day and may last for 2-3 weeks. This may becaused by the breast milk that might contain ß-glucuronidase, which deconjugates intestinalbilirubin and promotes its absorption and other inhibitors of glucuronyl transferase. Persistentlyhigh bilirubin levels may require changing from breast milk to infant formula for 24-48 h and/ortreatment with phototherapy, without cessation of breastfeeding.Breastfeeding jaundice (BFJ)It is an early-onset, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia of breastfed infants. Occurs in the 1st weekafter birth (usually appears after 24 - 72 hours of birth). It is due to decreased milk intake withdehydration and/or reduced caloric intake. The treatment would include continuing breastfeedingand supplementation with formula feeds if needed.

questions.question: A 26-year-old nursing mother presents with fever and pain in her left breast. She has haddifficulty with breastfeeding previously, and now examination reveals her left breast is warm,red, swollen, and painful to palpation. She was started on dicloxacillin. What advice should begiven to the mother regarding breastfeeding?

options.B: Continue feeding from both the breasts
options.C: Continue feeding from only right breast
options.D: Continue feeding from only left breast

questions.explanation: 115Lactational mastitis is not a contraindication to breastfeeding and the mother should continuefeeding on both breasts.It is most commonly caused due to Staphylococcus aureus present in the infant's nasopharynx.Dicloxacillin is safe to be given in nursing mothers.

questions.question: Which of the following statements are true with respect to the WHO Baby-Friendly HospitalInitiative for small, sick, and preterm newborns (2020)?

options.A: Paladai feeding is indicated in very preterm infants with no suck-swallow-breath coordination
options.B: Finger-feeding is optimally indicated for short-term use and may improve breastfeeding ratesat discharge
options.C: Feeding tubes are indicated only in neurologically compromised infants for long-term use
options.D: Bottle feeding can lead to overfeeding but has a reduced risk of aspiration in infants withimmature suck-swallow-breathe reflex

questions.explanation: Finger-feeding is optimally indicated for short-term use and may improve breastfeeding rates atdischarge. It is indicated in neurologically compromised and preterm infants for a short period oftime.Paladai feeding is indicated in preterm, late preterm, and term infants for supplementation. It iseconomic, cheap, and is easy to use and clean. It has a risk of aspiration and is a slower method offeeding.Feeding tubes- orogastric or nasogastric tubes are an efficient way of measuring intake. It isoptimally used in very preterm infants with no suck-swallow-breathe coordination for long-termuse. It requires frequent replacement.Bottle and teat feeding, though not recommended is an efficient way to feed. Slow-flow teatsmimic breastfeeding and are preferred to rapid-flow teats. They allow overfeeding and there is arisk of aspiration.116
